reviewText:
I expected a point-and-click adventure when I first read about Tiny Thief. And, in a way, it is, but in reality it's just another casual game with point-and-click adventure elements. Puzzles aren't hard to solve, they just require a bit of (random) mouse clicking and finding some of the secrets requires you to click on (seemingly) random objects. It's actually kinda fun, if only a little on the easy side. The secrets in the later levels are a bit harder to find, but give it enough time and you should be able to find them all. It won't take you hours to finish a level, just several minutes, depending on if you want to collect everything.

The animations are cute and the designs are colorful and seem targeted to a younger audience. That doesn't mean people who are a little older can't enjoy it. On the contrary. It's a game for everyone. The sounds and music are a little basic, but considering that it's ported from the iPhone it gets the job done I guess.

There are 5 worlds in total and finishing the game should take you a little over a couple of hours.
Is it worth €13,99 ? Hell no. Companies that charge this much don't deserve your money. Buy it in a sale and be happier that way.

[Rating: 75/100]

reviewText: Heres another game that i bought for my daughter and found myself getting really attached to (GOD I MUST DO SOME MORE ADULT GAMING).\nThe game is what i would call a point and click game but not in the same vein as games like the next big thing" or "runaway"

reviewText:
One of the many iOS ports that have reached Steam and this one works fairly well as the gameplay is really basic. Its not a game you get for the challenge but its a relaxing experience that works well to wind down or something to mess around with while you are doing something else (like watching a movie).

Pretty standard achievements with the usual 3 star completion achievements and the occational level specific achievement. Keep in mind that it has achievements for not using hints for up to 20 levels so avoid hints in-game if you can.

Time to 100%: ~6 hours

reviewText: I really did like Tiny Thief.  It's a puzzle/point-and-click adventure game. It kept reminding me of The Cave from earlier this year. Like those main characters, this tiny thief isn't all Robin Hood. One of the solutions is to tie a hot dog to some guy sleeping and push him in the water so he'll be too preoccupied being eaten by a shark to stop the thief from progressing on his way. The controls are really simple as this is a ported iOS game. The only input you need is the left-click to do everything in the game. The puzzles were moderately challenging and there are a lot of levels that have a good variety of locales and challenges. The sound design of the game is especially good. The music for each level is toe-tapping and the sound effects add a lot the charm of the game. It took me around 7 hours to 100% complete the game. This game makes a good case for the strength of mobile games. I highly recommend Tiny Thief.

reviewText:
Tiny Thief is exactly what I expected it to be, a point-and-click adventure. The puzzles are easy to solve, they just require a sliver of brain power; however, finding the secrets (like the golden eggs in Angry Birds [another Rovio game]) requires you to click on random objects. There is no reason or logic behind it, just random clicking will get you the secrets you need to three star every level.

That randomness aside, It is actually fun; even if it is a little on the easy side. The animations and story is cute and the designs are colorful and the game overall seems targeted at a younger audience. This does not mean that older audiences will not enjoy it, it should just be played casually and not to completion.

Overall, I spent six hours playing the game (pausing for lunch, dinner, and a snack) and got all of the achievements. This is a great game to get on a steam sale, but only on a steam sale as you can buy the same game through the App Store for $0.99.

So, buy the game, enjoy the cutesy story and animations and have some fun with Tiny Thief!

reviewText:
This game was an absolute joy to play. Even though it has the simplicity of just clicking where to go and what to make yourself do, it also gave you a challenge of figuring out where hidden objects were, when to go, what to do even though you know you CAN do it. -- If that makes any sense.

The graphics were smooth and adorable! Never any lag and my computer was not build for gaming AT ALL. Surprisingly, for such a simple game of puzzles and comics, it had a very sweet story line that was easy to follow. Not only that, but it was a great relief to be able to sit back, enjoy a cute puzzle, and not have to get a headache from constant dialogue.

Overall Review: 8/10.
Why an 8? Because even though it is a FANTASTIC game, 1: it's not for everyone, 2: it could have been longer. (I wish it was longer!)

reviewText:
A great game to fill plenty of those 10 - 20 min gaps while you're waiting to be somewhere else or to be doing something else. (This was my breakfast time & travel companion for several weeks.)  Each level is complete in itself and takes about that long to finish.

Tiny Thief is charming, light-hearted and frequently amusing.  The main puzzle in each level is reasonably straightforward if you're just after a speedy playthrough, but if you're up for a challenge, many of the secrets are pretty tough & keep you busy for longer.

I played this on a touchscreen device, so can't comment on the mouse & keyboard controls.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: It's fairly entertaining for what's quite obviously a tablet game port.  I wish they had changed some of the controls when they ported this over to the computer though.  Some tool tips or labels on the icons for the main menu would have also been nice instead of having to randomly click around to see what everything does.  Once you're in the game, the tablet style controls can feel a little clunky at times, but you tend to get mostly used to them after a bit.\n\nGenerally this game seems more like a puzzle game than an adventure game to me.  Expect to do a lot of random clicking on everything in the background if you want to collect all the items in each level.  You'll also more than likely end up replaying some of the levels several times if you happened to miss an extra objective when it was first there since after the beginning levels you can only get some of the extras at very specific points of progress during the level.  That can get a little aggrivating at times, but it's generally not too big of a deal since you can blast through a level fairly quick once you know how to finish it.  Overall it's a decent game you could either take in short bursts or run through the entire thing in what's starting to look like 6-8 hours or so (I'm around halfway through as of this review).  You're probably better off just getting it on a tablet instead if you have one, I can't imagine the port really adds anything to the game over the mobile version.  Plus with the control scheme, it'd be more natural on a tablet.

reviewText: This game was worth every penny. Love the art and music style. Cute animations but the theme really works. The controls are incredibly simple but not patronizingly so. The levels are fun, ingrossing and very clever. I have really enjoyed everything about this game. I especially enjoy the speed at which the difficulty ramps up. The pace is very good, easy in the beginning but no so easy that you lose interest. The levels definitely pick up as you go along but I never hit a point where I wanted to give up (no irregular difficulty spikes). My only concern with this game is that it was over so fast. I really hope they make a sequel.

reviewText: very excited i just finished this game. Overall very entertaining game, with cute little high jinx though out. Not much of a replay value and i was able to 100% completly the game very easily. but i would say i really enjoyed my time with this game. The only negative i really have to say is that there is a lot of patience i suppose involved, with not being able to skip past cut scenes and having to wait for actions to play through out, along with actions sometimes not registering. but i suppose the patience of it really sets the tone and atmosphere of the game which like i stated before is very enjoyable. The game is point and click, and significantly easier than most point and click games that are featured on steam ( no pixel hunting required!! the game offers a very clear method of pointing out what items are active to use ) i would say the game is most defiantly suitable for children .... and maybe even aimed more towards them lol with the ease of it. but there defiantly are more challenging levels where it had me scratchin my head and staring at the screen for a while trying to figure it out. so it is farily easy comparitive to most point and clicks, but not so challenging where you will become aggrivated... it's a rewarding aggrivated! lol any ways i really enjoyed and game and would recommend it .. and if $15 is too much for your finacial situation i hear there is a $3 app version which seems to be the exact same game.

reviewText: Do I think this game is worth playing: absolutely! Do I think the game is worth buying at the full price: definitely no!\n\nTiny Thief" is basically a point-and-click adventure game of the old style (and even pays homage to many of the classics)
date: but instead of a long uninterrupted narrative
recommended: it has been boiled down to byte-sized chapters/levels that are more appropriate for consumption in the current age of mobile gaming. Most of the elements are still there - the absurd combinations
voteText: even the sometimes aimless clicking around - but at the same time due to it being divided into levels the longer narrative and the more complex and longer puzzles are somewhat lacking. However
helpfulPercent: the levels still manage to combine into a good (although a bit simplistic) story and the gameplay is very enjoyable in its streamlined implementation (this
votesTotal: is the product of being a mobile game first and foremost).\n\nThe two things that set "Tiny Thief" apart and elevate it onto an even higher level of enjoyment are its art direction and animation which are indeed word class and set the game apart. I would recommend buying the game even for these two aspects
votesFunny: but would still ask you to only hand over the money when the game is on sale at a very steep discount - paying over ten times more for the same title as the one on mobile platforms is definitely absurd!"

reviewText: I've really been enjoying playing this game bit by bit. When I only have 10 minutes and want to play something fun and not too mentally taxing, this is definitely my game of choice. The animations are great, and I really like the graphics. The puzzles aren't very complicated--it's basically advanced hide-and-seek, but again, it's a casual game, not Broken Sword.\n\nI think kids would probably like it a lot, and it would be a nice intro to point and click.

reviewText: Instead of complaining about the price (which has dropped considerably since most of the negative reviews were written, yet the authors have not revisited their own reviews), I'll just state that it's a very cute, amusing little game and let you know that it took me 7 hours to get 100 percent.  It's up to you whether you think that's worth your money.  Bear in mind that the only replay value would be in watching the story unfold again and seeing if you can remember all the tricks and secrets.  I enjoyed every minute of it and got a lot of chuckles, so yes, I do feel like it was well worth the money I spent. ($6).  If you have an Apple or Android mobile device, you can save a few bucks by getting it there.  I like playing on a bigger screen, so I didn't mind paying a bit extra for the PC version.
voteText: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Tiny Thief
Rating: 8 / 10

More and more we see (successful) games ported from iOs to PC and this game also falls in that category. Often the port shows, especially when a game uses 3D models. However in this case the port is just excellent. This is due to the great mechanics, visual style and the way you (can) play the game.

You basically are a thief that has to do his tricks in 70+ levels by hitting the right buttons at the right time. Most of the time you walk to a point where an action appears that you have to do. Think about grabbing something, use an item or hiding in a barrel.

This sounds simple, and it is in the beginning. The difficulty gradually goes up and later on you have to time your actions correctly and in order to complete the level. Most levels have extra bonuses and a fret you have to detect to get the maximum score of three stars. When you complete your main objective you can run for the exit. But watch out, because when they see you you can try again.

Levels take a maximum of 5 minutes to complete so the size of the bite is great and I often start it up when I had nothing to do for 10 minutes or so.

Graphics are nicely done having  a cartoonish look, sound is great and there is lots of humour around. Just buy it and enjoy the puzzles I say!

reviewText: It's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, over-priced game. The animations are the only good thing about this point-and-click failure; otherwise, it's just a failed attempt at making a young blonde monk mimic Robin Hood (without any decent storytelling elements.) It's $0.99 on Google Play, so why would it cost so damn much on Steam? Simple. It's Rovio. Y'know, the same guys who released made Angry Birds $49.99 on consoles? Yeah, I regret every penny I thoughtlessly spent. This certainly isn't a gem; in fact, it isn't even a rock. It's just ♥♥♥♥.\n\n... At least it looks nice on paper, right?

reviewText:
Tiny Thief is adorable and an entertaining diversion but those two qualities in no way make up for the asking price, and the length of play time. I beat it (without going for all achievements) in a little over four hours. I enjoyed playing and found the story cute and fun, I enjoyed the puzzles, and found the humor spot on. I did, however, pick this up during a Steam Sale for 4.50 so I'm not too upset about the purchase. I would have felt much differently if I had paid the full asking price though.

There is almost no replay value if you get all three stars on every level the first time around (it isn't that difficult to do so), and once that's done the only reason to go back is for the achievements, most of which you should pick up the first time through.

If you absolutely must own this game, pick it up on your smartphone or tablet, where the price is a whopping 2.99. This game is, in no stretch of the imagination, worth 15.00.

reviewText: Rovio studios did an amazing job with Tiny Thief, and though I bought it while on Steam Summer Sale I would have paid more in hindsight for the amount of entertainment I've had playing it. reviewText: A cute little game. Neither very hard nor very long but with a nice sense of humor. Maybe get it when it's on sale (as I did) because you can easily play it through in one go (my play time of 7hrs include several breaks where I didn't bother closing the game, so the actual time I spent playing should be at least 2hrs less - I had it running in windows mode btw.) and I don't see much replay value. Oh, for those who care about these things: the whole game is played with the mouse - no keyboard input needed - which makes it a nice game to play while leaning back and having something to drink or eat in the other hand. A true casual game. :)

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Tiny Thief can be simply coined as an adorable stealth/puzzle game. You play a tiny thief who really sticks it to the man by stealing everything expensive the man owns, and in the process, becoming an olden day Robin Hood (or maybe current Robin Hood as this is medieval). This game is a product of 5 Ants and Rovio Stars, a start up initiative by Rovio Entertainment, the multi-trillion dollar empire that bought us Angry Birds.

I bought this game for Steam and found that the price far exceeds what the game delivers in hours of play. Then once I started to look into reviewing this game, I realised that it had been original developed for the phone, which made all the sense as it’s a single click game. It would be better played on the system it’s designed for and you can also buy it for the phone for a quarter of the price or less. So I suggest everyone does that.

For full review, visit:
http://icarusreviews.net/2014/01/10/tiny-thief/

reviewText:
Loved it. It's really funny, nice settings, beautiful artwork. Once you completed the main story, you can start all over again and try to get three stars in every level. A lot of hidden interacting possibilities might turn up.
It might not be this interesting for people who love to smash on their whole keyboard while playing because you only have to point with your mouse and click. That's it.

The game is also available for portable devices but I liked having a big monitor and seeing all the small details and having a great overview.

reviewText: Tiny Thief is a very pleasant game with great, cute design and funny plot. The music used in the game is vivid and reminds of the one that exists in animated series. The gameplay is short, the puzzles intriguing and the achievements can be earned with average effort.

reviewText: This is a great game for all ages, as long as you're interested in a simplistic puzzle game that doesn't offer an immense challenge. It took me maybe 10 hours to beat it but I enjoyed every second and I had a great time playing it. The art style is really cute and the levels are unique every time utilizing new types of puzzles and it's not repetitive in the least. The challenge progresses nicely but never becomes very difficult. I highly recommend to anyone thats looking to relax and enjoy themselves playing a cute little puzzle game for a few hours.
